moves.1. e4 e5 2. d4 d6: We free up our queens and bishops with these moves...
moves.3. dxe5 dxe5: ...then we swap pawns, opening up the d-file...
moves.4. Qxd8+: ...then I take his queen to force his king out of his initial position, so he can't castle...
moves.4... Kxd8: ...and he is forced to take mine.
moves.7. O-O-O+: ...and my last two moves allow me to castle queenside, instantly checking.
moves.7... Nbd7: He brings out his other knight...
moves.8. Nd5: ..then I fork its twin and his bishop...
moves.9... e4 10. Rd4: Now I line up his pawn...
moves.11... Nf6: ...and his knight forks my rook and d-pawn...
moves.15... Ke7: ...and he moves his king to unpin his knight...
moves.16. Bc4: ...and I line it up with my bishop, along with his bishop...
moves.20... Rhf8: He unleashes one of his own rooks...
moves.21. Ng5: ...so I put my knight on the attack, in retaliation to being a pawn down.
moves.21... Rf6: He fails to cover his h-pawn...
moves.22. Nxh7: ...so I accept it, to draw level, attacking his rook...
moves.23. Ng5: ...so I fork it, along with his e-pawn, which cannot leave its file...
moves.24... Rc8: Because he didn't move his king...
moves.25. Nxg7+: ...I can accept another pawn with my knight, which attacks his rook, and exposes his king to mine...
moves.27. Rf1+: Now I unleash my other rook to drive the king towards the side of the board...
moves.32... Ke7: He doesn't move his remaining rook...
moves.34... Kf7 35. Rg4 Nf5 36. Rf4: Now I pin his knight down...
moves.36... Ke6 37. Rxf5: ...and decide that with a two pawn advantage, with the extra two pawns on the kingside being passed, it's worth removing the knight...
moves.38. Kd2: Now I move up my king to eliminate his pawns...
moves.38... Kg4 39. Kd3 c5 40. Kc4 b6: ...but at the moment, my king can only touch the a-pawn...
moves.41. Kb5 Kh5 42. Ka6: ...so I move him diagonally to attack them.
moves.43... b5 44. Kb6 b4 45. Kb5 b3 46. axb3: ...but have to use a pawn for the second, to prevent my opponent 's pawn from reaching my bottom rank...
moves.47. cxb3: ...so I use another to eliminate the last pawn.
moves.47... Kg4 48. Kc4 Kh3: As his king moves behind my pawn furthest forward...
moves.52... Kd1 53. Qh2: Now I move my queen back to pin the king to my bottom rank...
moves.54... Kb1 55. b4: ...and move up my b-3 pawn to give my b-2 pawn room to move...
moves.55... Ka2: ...and my opponent's king tries to escape...
moves.56. b5: ...so I move my pawn again to keep the route blocked by the b-2 pawn, blocking a3, and my king blocking b3...
moves.56... Ka1 57. b3: ...so I move up my pawn to keep the king boxed in on my bottom rank...
moves.57... Kb1 58. Qd2: ...and my queen ensures he can only move between two squares...
moves.58... Ka1 59. Kc3: ...and my king gets into the position for my queen to trap my opponent's king. If he hadn't resigned, he would have gone 59... Kb1, and I would have gone 60. Qb2#.
